author: By Mike Isaac
title: Meta’s ‘Twitter Killer’ App Is Coming
description: Meta, which owns Facebook and Instagram, teased a new app called Threads that is set to take on Twitter for real-time digital conversations.
content: Mark Zuckerberg has long wanted to dislodge Twitter and provide the central place for public conversation online. Yet Twitter has remained stubbornly irreplaceable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: David Adjaye Relinquishes Roles After Reported Accusations of Misconduct
description: The acclaimed architect stepped back from a number of positions after The Financial Times reported that he had been accused of sexual assault. Mr. Adjaye called the allegations “untrue.”
content: David Adjaye, the acclaimed Ghanaian British architect who designed the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture, in Washington, D.C., stepped back from a number of roles Tuesday after The Financial Times reported that three former employees had accused him of sexual harassment and misconduct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin P. Clarke
title: Putin Created a Beast, and Now He Has No Idea How to Rein It In
description: After Yevgeny Prigozhin’s failed mutiny, Vladimir Putin must now figure out what to do with Wagner troops in Latin America, the Middle East and Africa.
content: For years, Yevgeny Prigozhin’s sprawling private army has quietly acted as a proxy for Russian foreign policy. The Wagner force’s network of thousands of Russian mercenaries installed in Latin America, the Middle East and Africa has helped the Kremlin secure natural resources and project influence in failed states and conflict zones while allowing President Vladimir Putin of Russia to conveniently distance himself from the group’s unsavory alliances and ruthless tactics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Choe Sang-Hun
title: Scientists Say Fukushima Water Is Safe, but Radiation Fears Persist
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency’s final report declared the treated water from the destroyed nuclear plant had met its safety standards. Critics continue to demand more transparency.
content: In one of the remaining steps before Japan decides to release more than one million metric tons of treated radioactive water from the Fukushima nuclear plant into the Pacific Ocean, the International Atomic Energy Agency declared on Tuesday that the government’s plan had met the agency’s safety standards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Brooke
title: How a 14-Minute Video on Posture Changed My Life
description: Hint: It wasn’t because it fixed the way I stood or sat. It has nothing to do with posture at all.
content: The world is loud and full of interruptions, from the phone buzzing in your pocket to the garbage truck backing up outside your window. It’s rare to find yourself in an environment that is totally tranquil — rarer still to be in a head space where you’re able to dissolve into that bubble of peace. I crave this feeling, which I associate with sitting in a darkened eye doctor’s office, listening to the soft click of the phoropter. I think of doing homework alone in the dining room of a childhood piano teacher’s house on winter evenings, waiting for my sister to finish her lesson. Or, more recently, of the windowless phone booths in the newsroom where I used to work, which I’d sometimes use not to conduct an interview but to sit on the floor when I was feeling overwhelmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: What We Celebrate When We Celebrate the Fourth of July
description: Abraham Lincoln knew why Thomas Jefferson mattered.
content: In the spring of 1859, Abraham Lincoln was invited by a committee of Boston Republicans to attend a festival in honor of Thomas Jefferson’s birthday. He couldn’t make it. Instead, he sent a letter that explains, perhaps better than anything else Lincoln wrote except for the Gettysburg Address, what it is that we celebrate when we celebrate the Fourth of July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Tara Koch
title: In Scotland, Taking the Traditional and Making It New
description: Tartan, whisky, restaurants in the middle of nowhere — all are being reimagined in newly fashionable “Outlander” territory.
content: Cool-kid chefs turning local bounty into Michelin-worthy dishes, an artisan whisky boom and a clutch of stylish hotels have helped Scotland shrug off its saturnine image and rebrand as a misty, moody mecca.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Gray Suit Takes Center Stage
description: Thom Browne makes his couture debut, while Schiaparelli, Dior and Iris Van Herpen spin their own dreamy tales.
content: In 1955 the idea of the gray flannel suit as the symbol of the soul-deadened corporate drone entered the American lexicon thanks to Sloan Wilson’s novel, making it pretty much impossible to look at that particular item of clothing in a neutral way ever again. It became the stand-in for our skewed work-life balance, the triumph of business over imagination. It got, it’s fair to say, a bad rep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Nathan’s Hot Dog Contest Finds Familiar Winners Amid Unexpected Drama
description: Joey Chestnut and Miki Sudo defended their titles, but the spectacle was less about the victors, and more about the journey, which this year included torrential rain.
content: The spectators lined up shoulder to shoulder in Coney Island on Tuesday, many sporting headwear that captured the essence of the day: Nathan’s foam hot dog hats or blue caps provided by an antacid company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Aaron Boxerman
title: Rockets Launched From Gaza Amid Israeli Raid in West Bank and Tel Aviv Attack
description: The launches into Israel came after a military incursion into the Palestinian city of Jenin left at least 12 Palestinians and one Israeli soldier dead.
content: Hours after Israel’s leader said a large-scale military incursion aimed at rooting out Palestinian armed groups in the West Bank city of Jenin was wrapping up, five rockets were fired from the Gaza Strip into Israel early Wednesday, raising fears of an escalation of tit-for-tat violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: A Solemn Walk Through Highland Park One Year After Parade Massacre
description: Residents of the Chicago suburb marched down Central Avenue as they do every Fourth of July. But this was no parade.
content: There were no marching bands this year. No floats. No church groups tossing snacks to spectators. No American flags lining the sidewalks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: Where to Celebrate a City Hall Wedding, and More Reader Questions
description: The “oops, all French” edition.
content: Happy Independence Day! This is by far one of my favorite days to be in the city. The fireworks (both legal and illegal), the big “we outside” energy, the ample parking. You love to see it. So make the most of the holiday, even if it’s just lazing around and catching up on “Love Island UK” to remind you why we wanted independence in the first place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Republicans Are Divided on Impeaching Biden as Panel Begins New Inquiry
description: A vote to send the Homeland Security Committee impeachment articles against President Biden for his border policies has underscored rifts in the G.O.P. about whether to try to remove him, and for what.
content: Republicans are deeply divided over impeaching President Biden, with newly energized lawmakers on the far right applying pressure to do so and leaders and rank-and-file members concerned they have undertaken a politically risky battle that they cannot win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Carlos Alcaraz Has Been Studying the Grass Court Masters. That Means Andy Murray.
description: On a day many matches were rained out at the All England Club, Alcaraz displayed his continued improvement on grass, and what he has learned from Murray.
content: Carlos Alcaraz took a little time to rest after coming up short in the French Open last month, and then he embarked on the next step toward strengthening one of the few remaining weaknesses in his tennis development — playing on grass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Henneberg
title: Why Abortion Stories Matter
description: The stories abortion doctors tell about their work play a vital role in exposing the substandard care endured by patients since Dobbs.
content: Start with a story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Criticism of Jewelry Sale With Nazi Shadow Trails Christie’s
description: Jewish organizations have rejected donations from the auction house, which sold gems from an estate that profited during the Holocaust.
content: Facing criticism for its sale of jewelry from an estate partly built on profits made from the purchase of Jewish businesses during the Holocaust, Christie’s promised in spring to donate a portion of its proceeds to further Holocaust research and education. But the auction house has struggled to find organizations willing to accept money from the sale, which went forward despite the objections of Jewish groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli
title: The Surprising Striver in the World’s Space Business
description: With at least 140 registered space-tech start-ups, India stands to transform the planet’s connection to the final frontier.
content: When it launched its first rocket in 1963, India was a poor country pursuing the world’s most cutting-edge technology. That projectile, its nose cone wheeled to the launchpad by a bicycle, put a small payload 124 miles above the Earth. India was barely pretending to keep up with the United States and the Soviet Union.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 4, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, July 4, 2023.
content: An article on Sunday about a prosecutor’s defense of the integrity of the Hunter Biden investigation incorrectly described what Attorney General Merrick B. Garland had said regarding special powers for David C. Weiss, the U.S. attorney in Delaware. Mr. Garland said that Mr. Weiss had not asked to be named a special counsel. Mr. Garland did not address whether Mr. Weiss had asked to be a special attorney.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘My Entire Body Shook With Passionate Interest’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: While I was dancing, another grad student said, “I know someone who dances just like you.” “No one dances like me,” I said; besides, I was pursuing women. But next semester, when I saw Steve, a decidedly male student in a turtleneck, my entire body shook with passionate interest. Later, when I saw him dance, I was offended: “I don’t dance like that!” Funny, though, that my dancing that night captured his interest. Within four months of meeting, I proposed marriage on July 4 weekend. Four months later, he said yes. Now, long married, we are still dancing, somewhat alike. — Michelle Mood
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Lewis Branscomb, Champion of Science Across Fields, Dies at 96
description: He led scientific advances at I.B.M. and within the federal government during a career that spanned the space race and the dawn of the internet.
content: As the Cold War was waning, the physicist Lewis Branscomb feared that America’s economic and scientific superiority was in jeopardy. Declining scientific literacy and critical thinking in American education, he believed, could have disastrous consequences for the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Biden Versus the Bad News Bros
description: No, the good economic data isn’t fake.
content: What Richard Hofstadter called the paranoid style in American politics is no longer a fringe phenomenon: Bizarre conspiracy theories are now mainstream on the American right. And one manifestation of this paranoia is the persistent dismissal of positive economic data as fake when a Democrat occupies the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly, Mark Walker and Ella Koeze
title: The Frequent Fliers of Congress Consider New Flights for Washington Airport
description: Dozens of lawmakers are seeking to loosen a law that limits long-distance flights to and from Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport. For some of them, success could mean a shorter commute.
content: Representative Blake D. Moore, Republican of Utah, is pushing for changes to federal law that would allow more nonstop flights between Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport and Salt Lake City. Those flights, he said, would increase tourism between Utah and the nation’s capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Prominent Russian Journalist Injured in Attack in Chechnya
description: Elena Milashina, known for her work on human rights, was assaulted along with Alexander Nemov, a lawyer.
content: A Russian investigative journalist and a lawyer were severely beaten in the southern Russian region of Chechnya on Tuesday, in an attack that stood out for its brutality in a country accustomed to the steady restriction of freedom of speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: 3 Are Fatally Shot in Fort Worth, Police Say
description: The shooting took place just before midnight on Monday in the Como neighborhood, southwest of downtown, the authorities said.
content: Three people were killed and eight others were injured in Fort Worth late Monday night when several men started firing indiscriminately into a crowd, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Was the Supreme Court Right to Block Biden’s Student Loan Forgiveness Plan?
description: Readers offer their opinions as well as ideas for alternatives. Also: Grief and “The Bear”; straight spouses left behind; Brazil’s example for the U.S.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin and Amanda Holpuch
title: Quick-Moving Wildfire in Washington Threatens Homes and Residents
description: The Tunnel Five Fire has destroyed 10 homes and burned more than 530 acres in Skamania County, Wash., near the state’s border with Oregon, the authorities said.
content: Firefighters in southwestern Washington were working on Tuesday to extinguish a wildfire that has destroyed 10 homes and burned more than 530 acres since it broke out on Sunday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: Raf’s Conjures Swirling Abundance from a Wood-Fired Oven
description: The workhorse oven of a longtime bakery now crackles under the command of the chefs from the Musket Room, Mary Attea and Camari Mick.
content: Early this year, the owners of the Musket Room, on Elizabeth Street, opened a second restaurant called Raf’s about one block north. Mary Attea is the chef at both, and intelligent, well-constructed food is the rule, but the cooking is so different it’s often hard to believe the same person is in charge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Edward Fredkin, 88, Who Saw the Universe as One Big Computer, Dies
description: An influential M.I.T. professor and an outside-the-box scientific theorist, he gained fame with unorthodox views as a pioneer in digital physics.
content: Edward Fredkin, who despite never having graduated from college became an influential professor of computer science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a pioneer in artificial intelligence and a maverick theorist who championed the idea that the entire universe might function like one big computer, died on June 13 in Brookline, Mass. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Seth Gilbert
title: Your Room Is Ready. Don’t Mind the Picket Line.
description: Hotel workers are on strike in Los Angeles as thousands of tourists, wedding guests and visitors have arrived in the city over the Fourth of July holiday.
content: Inside the InterContinental Los Angeles Downtown, a towering luxury hotel with a rooftop pool and soaring views of the city, Jason Hernandez said on Monday that things seemed normal. Housekeepers had cleaned his room. The lobby was tidy, if a little quiet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Greiving
title: Her Symphony Reclaims an Ancestral Story, and Classical Music
description: Tamar-kali, a former punk rocker, wove episodes of Gullah Geechee history into “Sea Island Symphony,” premiering at Lincoln Center in Manhattan.
content: When the composer Tamar-kali goes fishing in the South Carolina low country, she thinks about her ancestors — the Gullah Geechee — singing spirituals like “Wade in the Water.” And she pictures Harriet Tubman arriving with Union gunboats in the summer of 1863 when those ancestors actually had to wade in the water to their freedom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: How William Byrd Influences Music, 400 Years After His Death
description: Four popular composers explain how this Englishman’s ideas ricochet through their own works today.
content: The works of William Byrd hold significant historical interest, but they are also remarkably influential on music that is being written today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Léon Gautier, Last Surviving French Commando From D-Day, Dies at 100
description: “We were at the head of the landing,” he said. “The British let us go a few meters in front. For us it was the liberation of France, the return into the family.”
content: Léon Gautier, the last surviving member of an elite French unit that joined Allied forces in the D-Day invasion to wrest Normandy from Nazi Germany’s control, has died at 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Minjee Lee Doesn’t Want Golf to Be Easy
description: Before the U.S. Women’s Open, the reigning champion talked with The Times about the importance of taking time off, the joy of wind and why the women’s tour must play golf’s iconic courses.
content: Minjee Lee has spent these past few years feeling golf’s glories and agonies more than most.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and David McCabe
title: Federal Judge Limits Biden Officials’ Contacts With Social Media Sites
description: The order came in a lawsuit filed by the attorneys general of Missouri and Louisiana, who claim the administration is trying to silence its critics.
content: A federal judge in Louisiana on Tuesday restricted the Biden administration from communicating with social media platforms about broad swaths of content online, a ruling that could curtail efforts to combat false and misleading narratives about the coronavirus pandemic and other issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: The ‘Quiet Disease’ Lingering in Our Mouths
description: Nearly half of U.S. adults over 30 show signs of gum disease, which can cause tooth loss. Here’s how to recognize and treat it.
content: If your spit is sometimes tinged pink at least a couple of times a week after you brush or floss, it’s possible you have early stage gum disease. But the troublesome condition can also have other surprising symptoms — or none at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Halberstadt
title: Maggie Harrison’s War on Wine
description: Her painstaking blends are dazzling diners and critics — and upending long-held notions about how winemaking is supposed to work.
content: I first met Maggie Harrison in 2018, when I was on vacation in Portland, Ore. I hadn’t planned to taste any wine, content to take in the city’s peculiar West Coast weirdness, but a friend who worked for a food magazine said that I had to meet this winemaker who worked like an artist. She might have used the word “genius.” I mentioned Harrison to another friend, who’s in the wine business. He echoed the recommendation, describing her ambiguously as a person who had “declared war on wine.” Everywhere I looked online, Harrison was receiving accolades for the results of an unorthodox approach to winemaking, which drew as much from painting — she has a condition known as synesthesia, in which information meant to stimulate one sense also stimulates others — as it did from traditional notions of taste and aroma. Some critics let on that her wines had the complexity, tension and narrative arc of a great artwork. So I sent Harrison an email and received a response that began unenthusiastically with, “Unfortunately it is well known that I don’t like all that many humans.” She seemed to mean it. Still, she agreed to see me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: America Had More Than One Founding and More Than One Set of Founders
description: The enemies of slavery gave new meaning to the Declaration of Independence.
content: Read today, the Declaration of Independence is a freedom document. It stands for absolute human equality and represents the highest ideals of the American republic. On July 4, we celebrate it as much as we celebrate independence itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: C.T.E. Found for First Time in Female Pro Athlete
description: Heather Anderson, an Australian rules football player, was found posthumously to have had the degenerative brain disease.
content: For the first time, the degenerative brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., has been diagnosed in a female professional athlete, researchers reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: Overlooked Stories
description: Reading suggestions for the Fourth of July holiday.
content: If you’re spending this Fourth of July holiday in the U.S. grilling or setting off Roman candles, we hope you have some time to take a break and read. Today, we have suggestions for readers anywhere in the world — 25 of the best stories from The Times this year so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Putin, Xi, Modi Meet in Virtual Summit
description: Also, an attack in Tel Aviv as the death toll rises in Jenin.
content: The leaders of Russia, China and India — the three biggest powers bidding to reshape a global order dominated by the U.S. — convened over video at a virtual summit meeting of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, and each focused on their own driving issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saam Niami
title: Written in the Stars? More Like Written by A.I.
description: A new machine furthers a technology company’s aims at providing astrological readings using artificial intelligence.
content: The machine stood beside a deli counter, towering over cardboard boxes piled near the entrance to the Iconic Magazines store in NoLIta. It had the stature of a standing washer-dryer, with black buttons, rows of blinking lights and gauges labeled with celestial bodies — “sun,” “moon,” and the eight planets — on the front of its white facade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Jazmine Ulloa
title: The Republican Who Didn’t Campaign on Independence Day? Trump.
description: “Can you imagine Trump walking in the Wolfeboro Fourth of July parade?” a Republican consultant in New Hampshire asked. “I don’t think so.”
content: It’s the final Fourth of July before the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary — still more than six months away, yes. But all the same, the Republicans vying for their party’s presidential nomination were on the trail, waving to supporters from parades, shaking hands with voters and taking selfies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Is It Freckle Juice? No, Freckle Tattoos.
description: You get a freckle tattoo, you get a freckle tattoo. Everybody gets a freckle tattoo!
content: On a recent June morning in Brooklyn, Chloe Sarre nearly drifted into sleep on a bed in a cozy room as a makeup artist used a needle dipped in a semipermanent liquid pigment to carefully prick about 20 microscopic dots across her cheeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Summer Setting in N.Y.C.
description: Barbara Lin’s Fourth of July puzzle is a classic.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Does the Hudson Valley Beat Malibu? Ask Lorraine Toussaint.
description: After losing her California home in the 2018 wildfires, the actress bought an early-19th-century farmhouse near Rhinebeck, N.Y.
content: The wildfire that destroyed Lorraine Toussaint’s house in Malibu, Calif., in November of 2018 did not leave her unsheltered — she had a rental apartment in Midtown Manhattan — but it did leave her unmoored.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Black Artists Say A.I. Shows Bias, With Algorithms Erasing Their History
description: Tech companies acknowledge machine-learning algorithms can perpetuate discrimination and need improvement.
content: The artist Stephanie Dinkins has long been a pioneer in combining art and technology in her Brooklyn-based practice. In May she was awarded $100,000 by the Guggenheim Museum for her groundbreaking innovations, including an ongoing series of interviews with Bina48, a humanoid robot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Israel’s Raid on Jenin, in Pictures
description: The major incursion into the West Bank city, which the military says is focused on rooting out militants, has left several dead and forced thousands from their homes.
content: Israel’s most forceful incursion into the occupied West Bank for years has entered another day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Secret Service Examining How Suspected Cocaine Ended Up at the White House
description: An initial test of the white powdery substance found inside the White House on Sunday evening showed it was cocaine. President Biden and his family were away when it was discovered.
content: A small amount of a white powdery substance was found in the White House on Sunday evening, according to a person familiar with the episode, and an initial test by emergency response workers determined that it was cocaine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson, Jon Hurdle and Joel Wolfram
title: In Philadelphia, a Mass Shooting Leaves Five Dead
description: In a neighborhood where violence is not uncommon, witnesses described an intense barrage. A suspect has been taken into custody.
content: Maybe this Fourth of July would be different. The gun violence that has plagued Philadelphia has been inching down, steadily. Perhaps Independence Day would pass without the bloodshed that has marred it in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William D. Cohan
title: No One Can Stop Rupert Murdoch. That’s Increasingly a Problem.
description: Why nobody can rein in the increasingly erratic patriarch of the Fox Corporation.
content: What do we make of Rupert Murdoch, the 92-year-old patriarch of the Fox Corporation, at this moment?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: A Year After July 4 Parade Shooting, Some Americans Rethink Big Gatherings
description: Concerns about gun violence at large public events leave some contemplating safety measures or even staying home.
content: Luca and Lennyn Fantasia, ages 7 and 5, were bouncing around the Park Ridge, Ill., Memorial Day parade in May in giddy holiday mode. They wore red, white and blue outfits, admired the marching band and darted in the street to scoop up hard candy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Zelensky Accuses Russia of Trying to Kill Georgia’s Former President Saakashvili
description: Mikheil Saakashvili, now a Ukrainian citizen, has been imprisoned in Georgia. He appeared frail and skeletal in a court appearance that renewed concerns about his treatment in prison.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Russia on Monday of using Georgia’s government to kill the former Georgian president Mikheil Saakashvili, who sought to distance his country from Moscow’s influence and later became a Ukrainian citizen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Keith Bradsher and Ana Swanson
title: Yellen’s China Visit Aims to Ease Tensions Amid Deep Divisions
description: Mutual skepticism between the United States and China over a wide range of economic and security issues has festered in recent years.
content: The last time a U.S. Treasury secretary visited China, Washington and Beijing were locked in a trade war, the Trump administration was preparing to label China a currency manipulator, and fraying relations between the two countries were roiling global markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: It’s Getting Hard to Stage a School Play Without Political Drama
description: At a time when lawmakers and parents are seeking to restrict what can and cannot be taught in classrooms, many teachers are seeing efforts to limit what can be staged in their auditoriums.
content: Stevie Ray Dallimore, an actor and teacher, had been running the theater program for a private boys’ school in Chattanooga for a decade, but he never faced a school year like this one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Amsterdam Tries to Dim the Glare on Its Red-Light District
description: The mayor wants to improve the neighborhood for residents, but sex workers oppose measures recently put in place. Now the city is looking to set up legal prostitution elsewhere.
content: It has been a goal sought after by Amsterdam for years: dissuading rowdy, brawling tourists from overtaking the red-light district.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Bison Return to Native American Lands, Revitalizing Sacred Rituals
description: More than a century after a mass bison slaughter, the animals are restoring Great Plains ecosystems and reinvigorating Indigenous customs like the sun dance.
content: For years, meals at the summer sun dance ceremonies on the Eastern Shoshone tribe’s lands in Wyoming were missing something that was once a staple of the sacred rituals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: ‘Silo’ Creator on the Show’s ‘Cautionary Tale’ About Tech
description: In an interview, Graham Yost discusses the Apple TV+ sci-fi series and the mysteries and revelations of its twisty season finale.
content: This interview includes spoilers for the first season of “Silo.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Hurdle and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Gunman Kills Four in Southwest Philadelphia, Police Say
description: The suspect was wearing body armor and three guns were recovered, the police said.
content: A heavily armed gunman wearing a bulletproof vest opened fire in southwest Philadelphia on Monday evening, killing four people and injuring two others, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Russia’s beleaguered embassy in Washington.
content: Every few weeks, a light show featuring the blue and yellow Ukrainian flag — and occasionally a Ukrainian-language profanity about the Russian president, Vladimir Putin — is beamed onto the white facade of the Russian Embassy in Washington. Russia has fought back with a big spotlight, umbrellas to obstruct the projections and illuminations of its own, such as two giant white Z’s, a nationalist Russian symbol of the war effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernard Mokam and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: A Summer Basketball Refuge Thrives in the Bronx’s Largest Housing Complex
description: Basketball gave Rasheem Jenkins “an escape from the reality of the projects.” Now he runs a summer league in the Bronx development where he grew up.
content: Jeremiah Peoples was alone on the fast break with the energy of the crowd fueling him to the rim. “Finish your breakfast!” the announcer boomed into the microphone. Mr. Peoples, a lanky 18-year-old, dunked with authority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Biden Sidesteps Any Notion That He’s a ‘Flaming Woke Warrior’
description: Despite his alliance with abortion-rights supporters and L.G.B.T.Q. advocates, the president has deftly avoided becoming enmeshed in battles over hotly contested social issues.
content: President Biden memorably jumped the gun on Barack Obama in endorsing same-sex marriage more than a decade ago, but at a June fund-raiser near San Francisco, he couldn’t recall the letters L.G.B.T.Q.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Sameer Yasir
title: Putin, Xi and Modi Meet on Camera, but With No Signs of Greater Unity
description: At a virtual summit meeting of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, the leaders of Russia, China and India each focused on their own driving issues.
content: The leaders represented the three biggest powers bidding to reshape a global order dominated by the United States, convening over video feeds at a virtual summit meeting on Tuesday. But beyond the unity implied by their joint appearance, each seemed focused on his own, different aim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: Samsung’s A.I. Moment Is Here, but Is It Ready?
description: Foreign investors betting on artificial intelligence are pouring money into the company’s shares. Analysts say it will have a hard time keeping up with rivals.
content: The introduction of ChatGPT has lit a fire under the shares of companies that produce microchips, the brains of artificial intelligence. Bets on the potential of so-called generative A.I. have poured in. The most eye-catching example of the rally is Silicon Valley’s Nvidia, the top seller of chips used in artificial intelligence, whose shares are up nearly 200 percent this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Jens Stoltenberg to Remain NATO Chief
description: After initially saying he would leave the job in September, NATO’s secretary general said he would stay on another year.
content: BRUSSELS — Jens Stoltenberg, the NATO secretary general, finally gave in. Having previously announced that he would leave the job this September, he reversed himself on Tuesday and said that he had agreed to extend his mandate another year, until October 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Olivia Rodrigo’s ‘Vampire’ Takes a Note From Taylor Swift: Leave a Mark
description: The pop singer’s new single dismantles a former paramour who was entranced by fame, borrowing a tactic from Swift’s career-shifting “Dear John.”
content: On “Drivers License,” one of the great singles of the 2020s, Olivia Rodrigo has been played for a fool by an ex, but the song — pulsing, parched, destitute — remains centered in her pathos. She may have been abandoned, but the person who did the damage is still an object of, if not exactly affection, then obsession: “I still hear your voice in the traffic/We’re laughing/Over all the noise.” At the song’s conclusion, she is alone, and lonely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Morris
title: William Byrd: An Essential English Composer for Four Centuries
description: As the music world celebrates the 400th anniversary of Byrd’s death, it looks back on an artist of nimble styles and stubborn beliefs.
content: When William Byrd died on July 4, 1623, the Cheque Book of the Chapel Royal noted the passing of “a Father of Musick.” That’s not an exaggeration: Today, his legacy as a composer flexible in style and firm in belief still resounds across England and the world of choral music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Alligator Kills 69-Year-Old Woman in South Carolina
description: The deadly attack in Hilton Head Island was the second fatal alligator attack in Beaufort County, S.C., in less than a year, the authorities said.
content: A 69-year-old woman was attacked and killed by an alligator on Tuesday as she was walking her dog in her neighborhood in Hilton Head Island, S.C., the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Missing Massachusetts Woman Is Found Stuck in Mud in a State Park
description: Emma Tetewsky, 31, had been missing for a week when hikers heard a woman screaming for help in Borderland State Park, south of Boston. The police said she may have been trapped for three days.
content: A Massachusetts woman who had been missing for a week was rescued on Monday after she was found stuck in mud in a state park south of Boston, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle
title: After Protests, France Holds Hasty Trials for Hundreds
description: The streets are calmer, after days of unrest over the police shooting of a teenager, but the courts are going into overdrive. Lawyers for those arrested often have just 30 minutes to prepare.
content: The clerks were on strike in the Nanterre courthouse, so the accused burglars, homeless thieves and domestic abusers had to wait. It was 5 p.m. by the time Yanis Linize was ushered into the courtroom, a few blocks from the traffic circle where young Nahel Merzouk was shot by a policeman just a week ago, setting off protests across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Shane
title: What Really Happened Inside This Nazi Brothel?
description: In “The Madam and the Spymaster,” a trio of journalists probe the story of a German bordello that purportedly doubled as a listening post.
content: The brothel owner Kitty Schmidt began to sneak portions of her savings out of Nazi Germany sometime in the mid-1930s, often by sending her girls to London with cash sewn in their underwear. By 1938, officials had caught on, but thanks to her police connections, she wasn’t formally charged with currency smuggling. Still, her time had come. If she wanted to flee the Third Reich, it had to be now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Hong Kong Offers Bounties as It Pursues Dissidents Overseas
description: The rewards of $128,000 for information leading to the prosecution of dissidents who have fled Hong Kong reflect stepped-up pressure to intimidate activists beyond the reach of the government.
content: Hong Kong’s top leader said Tuesday that eight dissidents who had fled overseas would be “pursued for life” with large rewards being offered in exchange for information leading to their prosecution.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Ukrainian Writer Dies After a Strike
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 4, 2023.
content: “So many books unwritten, stories untold, days unlived.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: About Those July 4 Fireworks and Air Pollution
description: As concerns over wildfires and air quality mount, drones and laser shows offer an alternative to fireworks on July 4 and other holidays.
content: The American practice of setting off fireworks on July 4 stretches back to the first Independence Day celebration in Philadelphia in 1777. Today, it’s a beloved tradition that almost seems impossible to replace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Jonathan Weisman
title: Stumping on July 4, Trump’s Rivals Pitch Themselves to Early-State Voters
description: Donald J. Trump loomed large over the campaign trail, even though he was among the few G.O.P. contenders who stayed away from it.
content: At a high school cafeteria in Merrimack, N.H., on Tuesday, where patriotic music blasted from the speakers and the lunch tables were decked in star-spangled napery, Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota mingled with families who were digging into eggs, sausage and pancakes at a Fourth of July breakfast hosted by the local Rotary Club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Missed Monday Night’s Supermoon? We’ve Got You Covered.
description: The July supermoon, also called the buck moon, is the first of four supermoons expected this year.
content: Stargazers and astrophiles from Los Angeles to Istanbul rushed outdoors to see the first supermoon of the year on Monday night. It did not disappoint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: On Race and Academia
description: After the Supreme Court’s ruling on affirmative action, I have some experiences to share.
content: The Supreme Court last week outlawed the use of race-based affirmative action in college admissions. That practice was understandable and even necessary 60 years ago. The question I have asked for some time was precisely how long it would be required to continue. I’d personally come to believe that preferences focused on socioeconomic factors — wealth, income, even neighborhood — would accomplish more good while requiring less straightforward unfairness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: How ‘Barbie’ Landed in Hot Water in Vietnam
description: Greta Gerwig’s upcoming film has been banned in the country for its use of a map depicting territory that both China and Vietnam claim as their own.
content: There will be no “Barbie” world in Vietnam this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Meta Loses Appeal on How It Harvests Data in Germany
description: The ruling by the European Court of Justice clears the way for Germany’s top antitrust enforcer to block Meta from combining user data across its platforms.
content: Meta’s ability to harvest data about users in order to sell personalized ads was thrown into question on Tuesday after the European Union’s highest court upheld a decision by German antitrust regulators that the company had abused its dominance in social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Jenin Has a Long Legacy as a Bastion of Palestinian Armed Struggle
description: In the northern reaches of the occupied West Bank, near the boundary with Israel, Jenin and its refugee camp have nurtured an ethos of defiance.
content: As Israeli forces hunted for wanted men, weapons and explosives in the Palestinian refugee camp in Jenin this week, after using aerial drones to blow up what they described as terrorist hubs there, the city was living up to its reputation as a center of militant defiance in the occupied West Bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Fauci
title: Anthony Fauci on Larry Kramer and Loving Difficult People
description: He remembers his friend the AIDS activist Larry Kramer.
content: I recently attended a memorial service for Larry Kramer, the award-winning playwright, author and provocative gay activist. It has been three years since Larry’s death, and a number of friends and colleagues gathered to pay him tribute at the Lucille Lortel Theater on Christopher Street in Greenwich Village, where his Obie Award-winning play, “The Destiny of Me,” opened in October 1992. I had a genuinely unique relationship with Larry for more than three decades, which I reflected on at his memorial and wanted to share here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben H. Winters
title: Secrets and Horrors at a Tragedy-Stricken Amusement Park
description: In Arianna Reiche’s debut novel, “At the End of Every Day,” a death at an amusement park leads to the discovery of a mysterious underworld lurking beneath the attractions.
content: An amusement park is a staggering operation. A massive campus, a long roster of employees, an extraordinary logistical undertaking, all organized toward the perfection of an illusion: In here, past the miles of parking lots and through the gates, lies a more ideal version of reality than the one you’ve left behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: After Armed Rebellion, Putin Tries to Reinforce His Defenses
description: Long focused on security, the Russian president is rewarding loyalty among the ruling elite and showering his most important constituency — the men with guns — with cash.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is said to work out of identically constructed offices at multiple residences so that photographs don’t reveal his location.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Corporate Landscaping Lets Its Hair Down
description: More companies are eschewing manicured grass in favor of native plants, a shift driven by the environmental costs of installing and maintaining lawns.
content: At its former headquarters in eastern Pennsylvania, Air Products had a neatly manicured lawn and boxwood hedges. But when the industrial gases company moved to nearby Allentown recently and erected a new office building, it tried something different.
source.name: The New York Times

title: At Home With Lorraine Toussaint
description: After losing her California home in the 2018 wildfires, the actress bought an early 19th-century farmhouse near Rhinebeck, N.Y.
content: After losing her California home in the 2018 wildfires, the actress bought an early 19th-century farmhouse near Rhinebeck, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spectee and The Associated Press
title: Tunnel Five Fire Burns Hundreds of Acres in Washington
description: An estimated 250 homes were threatened by the fire, and officials issued evacuation orders for residents in a two-mile radius.
content: An estimated 250 homes were threatened by the fire, and officials issued evacuation orders for residents in a two-mile radius.
source.name: The New York Times
